docs.lead_paragraph: U.S. Sen. Mary Landrieu has doubled down on her support for the federal health care law even as polls show the revamp remains unpopular in Louisiana and a new Republican attack ad launched Tuesday hits the Democratic incumbent again for her vote.

headline.main: Landrieu Sticks to Support for Obama's Health Law
headline.print_headline: Landrieu Sticks to Support for Obama's Health Law

docs.snippet: U.S. Sen. Mary Landrieu has doubled down on her support for the federal health care law even as polls show the revamp remains unpopular in Louisiana and a new Republican attack ad launched Tuesday hits the Democratic incumbent again for her vote.

docs.lead_paragraph: Britain's top equity index rebounded on Tuesday, helped by stronger mining stocks which offset a fall in banking shares such as Standard Chartered and Lloyds.

docs.snippet: Britain's top equity index rebounded on Tuesday, helped by stronger mining stocks which offset a fall in banking shares such as Standard Chartered and Lloyds.

docs.lead_paragraph: British bank Lloyds has taken another 900 million pound charge to compensate customers mis-sold loan insurance, delivering a further blow to the lender which only narrowly passed European health checks on the sector's finances.

headline.main: Lloyds Dealt New Blow With 900 Million Pound Mis-Selling Charge
headline.print_headline: Lloyds Dealt New Blow With 900 Million Pound Mis-Selling Charge

docs.lead_paragraph: Carol Shea-Porter and Ann McLane Kuster are locked in tight re-election battles with opponents who are eager to tie them to President Obama, who has a 40 percent approval rating here.

headline.main: In New Hampshire, House Incumbents Try to Prevent Another Flip of Seats
headline.print_headline: In New Hampshire, House Incumbents Try to Prevent Another Flip of Seats

docs.abstract: Carol Shea-Porter and Ann McLane Kuster, two House Democrats running for re-election in New Hampshire, are locked in tight re-election battles with opponents eager to tie them to President Obama, who has 40 percent approval rating in state; two races are playing out in genuine swing districts, which have swapped parties three times each in last four elections.
docs.snippet: Carol Shea-Porter and Ann McLane Kuster are locked in tight re-election battles with opponents who are eager to tie them to President Obama, who has a 40 percent approval rating here.

docs.lead_paragraph: A federal prosecutor said that the city and a contractor exploited Medicaid billing loopholes to collect tens of millions of dollars in reimbursements.

headline.main: New York City Agency and Vendor Bilked Medicaid, U.S. Says
headline.print_headline: City Is Accused in 5-Year Fraud Over Medicaid

docs.abstract: Federal authorities accuse New York City officials of five-year effort to defraud Medicaid; United States Atty for New York Preet Bharara says city's Dept of Health and Mental Hygiene worked with contractor Computer Sciences Corp from 2008 through 2012 to exploit loopholes in Medicaid's computerized billing system to collect reimbursements on tens of thousands of false claims that amounted to tens of millions of dollars.
docs.snippet: A federal prosecutor said that the city and a contractor exploited Medicaid billing loopholes to collect tens of millions of dollars in reimbursements.

docs.lead_paragraph: Martha Weinman Lear returns to the territory she covered in “Heartsounds,” but this is not a sequel so much as a rueful epilogue, a brief account of her own recent skirmish with heart disease.

headline.seo: Martha Weinman Lear Returns to Medical Memoir, With Less Fury, in ‘Echoes of Heartsounds’

docs.abstract: Dr Abigail Zuger reviews book Echoes of Heartsounds: A Memoir by Martha Weinman Lear.
docs.snippet: Martha Weinman Lear returns to the territory she covered in “Heartsounds,” but this is not a sequel so much as a rueful epilogue, a brief account of her own recent skirmish with heart disease.
